question: When the Regulator is considering whether to refuse to recognise a Foreign Resolution Action (in whole or in part) while also proposing to take Resolution Action in relation to an ADGM Branch pursuant to section 78(5), how do the preconditions for taking Resolution Action in respect of an ADGM Branch interact with the refusal ground that the Resolution Conditions have not been met?
gold_answer: If the Regulator proposes to take Resolution Action in relation to an ADGM Branch pursuant to section 78(5), it may refuse to recognise a Foreign Resolution Action (in whole or in part) where it is satisfied that the Resolution Conditions have not been met for the relevant entity. [#TGT:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba] For an ADGM Branch, those Resolution Conditions include that the Regulator is satisfied the branch is failing or likely to fail, that (considering timing and other relevant circumstances) it is not reasonably likely that other action by or in respect of the ADGM Branch or the Non-ADGM Institution will prevent that failure or likely failure, and that applying a Resolution Tool is in the public interest. [#SRC:f586c998-e0a5-470f-a8d5-ae1669514726] In addition, the Regulator must be satisfied about the Non-ADGM Institution’s status regarding Foreign Resolution Action or Non-ADGM Insolvency Proceedings—either it is not subject (and not likely within a reasonable timeframe to become subject) to such measures, or it is subject to Foreign Resolution Action and a specified circumstance applies. [#SRC:f586c998-e0a5-470f-a8d5-ae1669514726] Accordingly, if any of these ADGM-Branch-specific conditions are not met, that shortfall can support refusal of recognition under the ground tied to unmet Resolution Conditions in the section 78(5) context. [#TGT:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba]
source_text:
A Resolution Action may be taken in respect of an ADGM Branch only if the Regulator is satisfied that the following conditions are met—
(a)	the ADGM Branch is failing or is likely to fail;
(b)	having regard to timing and other relevant circumstances, it is not reasonably likely that any action will be taken by or in respect of the ADGM Branch or Non-ADGM Institution that will prevent the failure or likely failure of the ADGM Branch or Non-ADGM Institution;
(c)	the application of a Resolution Tool is in the public interest; and
(d)	the Non-ADGM Institution is—
(i)	not subject to, and not likely in a reasonable timeframe to be subject to, any Foreign Resolution Action or Non-ADGM Insolvency Proceedings; or
(ii)	subject to Foreign Resolution Action, and one of the circumstances referred to in section 78(2) applies in respect of the Non-ADGM Institution.

question: For investments made using Musharaka or Mudaraba contracts where commodities are the underlying assets, how must an Authorised Person calculate its Commodities Risk Capital Requirement, and how does that calculation method interact with the requirement for Category 1, 2 or 5 firms to calculate the requirement for Trading Book and Non Trading Book commodity positions using either an approved internal Market Risk model or the Section A6.5 rules?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that makes investments using Musharaka or Mudaraba contracts with commodities as the underlying assets must determine its Commodities Risk Capital Requirement by following PRU Rule 5.7.1. [#SRC:bbd0d60b-0179-4756-8de1-848cacc7db4e] Where that same Authorised Person is in Category 1, 2 or 5, it must also ensure that its Commodities Risk Capital Requirement is calculated for both Trading Book and Non Trading Book commodity positions using one of the two permitted approaches: either an internal Market Risk model that has been approved by the Regulator for this specific purpose, or the rules in Section A6.5. [#TGT:e93a335b-caf1-4776-842f-11bd1e28aefe] In practice, this means the firm must (i) identify that the relevant exposures arise from Musharaka or Mudaraba investments with commodity underlyings, triggering the PRU Rule 5.7.1 basis, and (ii) for Category 1, 2 or 5, apply that calculation across both Trading Book and Non Trading Book commodity positions through either the approved internal model route or the Section A6.5 route. [#SRC:bbd0d60b-0179-4756-8de1-848cacc7db4e] [#TGT:e93a335b-caf1-4776-842f-11bd1e28aefe]
source_text: Market risk. Where investments are made using Musharaka or Mudaraba contracts with commodities as the underlying assets, an Authorised Person must calculate its Commodities Risk Capital Requirement in accordance with PRU Rule 5.7.1.
target_text:
An Authorised Person in Category 1, 2 or 5 must calculate its Commodities Risk Capital Requirement in respect of Trading Book and Non Trading Book commodity positions by:
(a)	applying its internal Market Risk model which has been approved by the Regulator for this purpose; or
(b)	applying the Rules set out in Section A6.5.

question: For a Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity preparing its quarterly report, what information must the report contain (including any consolidated-basis requirement and the 12‑month reserves/resources disclosure cross-reference), and by when after quarter-end must the report required by Rule 12.13.1 be disclosed?
gold_answer: A Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity must both (i) include specified content in its quarterly report for each quarter of its financial year and (ii) disclose the Rule 12.13.1 report within a defined post‑quarter deadline. [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62] [#SRC:380ff25a-7805-4020-9f40-da991f91eab1] The quarterly report must cover the Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity and all controlled entities, prepared on a consolidated basis where applicable. [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62] It must include: details of Petroleum-related activities for Exploration (or a statement of no Exploration activity) and for production and development (or a statement of no mining production and development activity); a summary of expenditure incurred for Exploration and for production and development; Petroleum Tenements held at quarter-end with location and percentage interest (including beneficial interests in farm-in or farm-out agreements); and Petroleum Tenements (including those beneficial interests) acquired or disposed of during the quarter with their location. [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62] In addition, at least once every 12 months the report must address the Summary of Reserves and Resources required by Rule 12.14.1 unless that summary is included in the annual report, and it must state when the previous and upcoming disclosures of that summary were and are to be made. [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62] The Rule 12.13.1 quarterly report must be disclosed no later than one month after the end of the quarter. [#SRC:380ff25a-7805-4020-9f40-da991f91eab1]
source_text: Quarterly Reports – Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entities. A Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity must disclose the report required by Rule 12.13.1 no later than one month after the end of the quarter.

question: Where a Fund Manager identifies a material change, error, or omission after making the notification under Rule 3.1.2 but before Promotion begins in a Host Jurisdiction, what are the Fund Manager’s immediate notification duties, what must the Regulator do with that information, and how can that same type of issue lead to the Regulator taking measures up to de-registration if it results in non-compliance?
gold_answer: Between the notification under Rule 3.1.2 and the start of Promotion in a Host Jurisdiction, the Fund Manager must notify the Regulator in writing without delay if it becomes aware of any material change, error, or omission that is reasonably likely to be relevant to that notification. [#TGT:001f1eee-febb-4f75-97f2-429cb0f2fdd6] After receiving that notice, the Regulator must promptly pass all relevant details of the material change, error, or omission to the relevant Host Regulator. [#TGT:001f1eee-febb-4f75-97f2-429cb0f2fdd6] Separately, if a material change, error, or omission of the type referred to in Rule 3.1.9 results in the Fund Manager no longer complying with applicable legislation (including these Rules), the Regulator is required to take all due measures. [#SRC:05992880-f8db-4ec8-8e02-79ab08521207] Those measures can include, where necessary, de-registering the Private Fund from the Register of Passported Funds in accordance with these Rules, and the Regulator may also act where it otherwise considers action necessary and appropriate in the circumstances. [#SRC:05992880-f8db-4ec8-8e02-79ab08521207] In practice, the Fund Manager’s prompt written notice during the pre-Promotion window enables the Regulator’s onward communication to the Host Regulator while also informing whether the issue triggers due measures for non-compliance, potentially up to de-registration. [#TGT:001f1eee-febb-4f75-97f2-429cb0f2fdd6] [#SRC:05992880-f8db-4ec8-8e02-79ab08521207]
source_text: If, as a result of any material change, error, or omission referred to in Rule 3.1.9, the Fund Manager will no longer comply with applicable legislation, including these Rules, or if the Regulator otherwise considers it necessary and appropriate in the circumstances, the Regulator shall take all due measures, including, if necessary, the de-registration of the Private Fund from the Register of Passported Funds in accordance with these Rules.
target_text: If, at any time between the notification pursuant to Rule 3.1.2 and the commencement of Promotion in a Host Jurisdiction, the Fund Manager becomes aware of any material change, error, or omission reasonably likely to be relevant to such notification, the Fund Manager shall give written notice to the Regulator without delay. The Regulator will promptly provide the relevant Host Regulator with all relevant details of such material change, error or omission.

question: For a Third Party Provider’s Governing Contract, how should the contract’s required exchange-rate disclosures and any agreed approach to changing exchange rates be structured so that the provider can apply exchange-rate changes immediately and without notice only in the permitted cases?
gold_answer: A Third Party Provider should draft the Governing Contract so that (i) it includes the required baseline disclosures on exchange rates and (ii) it only permits immediate, no-notice exchange-rate changes in the limited situations allowed. The contract must, where relevant, state the exchange rates to be applied or, if Reference Exchange Rates are used, explain how the relevant date is determined for those Reference Exchange Rates. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] Where relevant and if agreed, it must also address how changes in Reference Exchange Rates will be applied and what information will be provided in relation to those changes. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] Against that disclosure framework, immediate application without notice is only appropriate where the Governing Contract expressly grants that right and the exchange-rate changes are based on Reference Exchange Rate information that has already been provided to the Customer in accordance with Rule 20.2.2, or where the change is more favourable to the Customer. [#SRC:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2] In practice, this means the contract’s “changes” provisions should be aligned with its exchange-rate/Reference Exchange Rate disclosures so the no-notice mechanism is not broader than these two permitted cases. [#SRC:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2] [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]
source_text:
Changes in contractual information. Changes in exchange rates may be applied immediately and without notice where:
(a)	such a right is agreed under the Governing Contract and any such changes in exchange rates are based on the Reference Exchange Rate information which has been provided to the Customer in accordance with Rule 20.2.2; or
(b)	the changes are more favourable to the Customer.

question: In assessing whether Behaviour involving effecting transactions or orders to trade that may create a false or misleading impression or secure an abnormal/artificial price is caught by the described category, how does the ability to establish that the conduct was for legitimate reasons and in conformity with an Accepted Market Practice affect the analysis?
gold_answer: Where the Behaviour consists of effecting transactions or orders to trade that give, or are likely to give, a false or misleading impression about supply, demand, or price, or that secure the price at an abnormal or artificial level, the described category is framed to apply when those transactions or orders are done other than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market. [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f] In that context, if a person can establish that they carried out the conduct or practice for legitimate reasons and in conformance with an Accepted Market Practice, that established showing aligns with the stated carve-out condition and therefore addresses the “otherwise than for legitimate reasons and in conformity” element embedded in the category description. [#SRC:277b5e91-5efc-4b1d-a2b2-790aa0039f73] Practically, the analysis turns on two linked components: (i) whether the transactions/orders have (or are likely to have) the misleading/price-securing effects described, and (ii) whether the person can demonstrate legitimate reasons and conformity with an Accepted Market Practice, which is the specific basis identified for treating the conduct as market practice rather than falling within the “otherwise than” framing. [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f] [#SRC:277b5e91-5efc-4b1d-a2b2-790aa0039f73]
source_text: Market Practice. If a person establishes that they carried out the conduct or practice for legitimate reasons and in conformance with an Accepted Market Practice (see section 92(4)).
target_text:
The third is where the Behaviour consists of effecting transactions or orders to trade (otherwise than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market) which—
(a)	give, or are likely to give, a false or misleading impression as to the supply of, or demand for, or as to the price of, one or more Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities; or
(b)	secure the price of one or more such instruments at an abnormal or artificial level.

question: If the Listing Authority checks a complaint and decides the information is accurate, is Inside Information, and is not exempt under Rule 7.2.2, what does it ask the Reporting Entity to do under Rule 7.2.1, and what kinds of questions would an ‘aware letter’ ask if the Listing Authority thinks the information should have been Disclosed earlier?
gold_answer: If the Listing Authority’s enquiry results in a view that the information is accurate, is Inside Information, and is not within the Rule 7.2.2 exemption from disclosure, it will ask the Reporting Entity to make a Disclosure about the matter under Rule 7.2.1. [#SRC:6f969623-b272-436b-9bad-c57a00efd944] When the Listing Authority also believes the information should have been Disclosed earlier, it may escalate by issuing an ‘aware letter’ (or taking other action), which is used to probe the Reporting Entity’s handling and timing of disclosure. [#SRC:6f969623-b272-436b-9bad-c57a00efd944] An aware letter generally follows a standard template that first identifies the information and notes the date it was Disclosed. [#TGT:f221a729-4fb2-4eca-bb45-6c892c667a28] It then asks whether the Reporting Entity considers that information to be Inside Information, described as information a reasonable person would expect to significantly affect the price of the Listed Entity’s Securities. [#TGT:f221a729-4fb2-4eca-bb45-6c892c667a28] If the Reporting Entity says “yes,” the letter typically asks when it first became aware of the Inside Information (including time and circumstances) and why it did not Disclose earlier or request a Trading Halt or Suspension earlier, with specific comments on Rule 7.2.1. [#TGT:f221a729-4fb2-4eca-bb45-6c892c667a28] If the Reporting Entity says “no,” it must explain the basis for that view and confirm compliance with the Markets Rules, especially Rule 7.2.1. [#TGT:f221a729-4fb2-4eca-bb45-6c892c667a28]
source_text:
SUPERVISION BY LISTING AUTHORITY
Complaints or allegations of non-compliance by Reporting Entities
If, as a result of the enquiry, the Listing Authority forms the view that the information is accurate, is Inside Information, and is not within exemption from Disclosure provided by Rule 7.2.2, the Listing Authority will ask the Reporting Entity to make a Disclosure about the matter under Rule 7.2.1.  If the information should have been Disclosed earlier, the Listing Authority may issue an ‘aware letter’ (see paragraphs 187 to 189 above), or take other relevant action.
target_text:
SUPERVISION BY LISTING AUTHORITY
Aware Letters
Similar to a MAQ Letter, ‘aware letters’ tend to follow a standard template.  Generally, they will identify the information in question and the relevant date it was Disclosed, and ask the following questions:

(i)	Does the Reporting Entity believe the information identified in the letter to be Inside Information (being information that a reasonable person would expect to have a significant effect on the price of the Listed Entity’s Securities)?

(ii)	If the answer to question i) is “yes”, please confirm the following:

i.	When did the Reporting Entity first become aware of the Inside Information identified in the letter? Please include details of the relevant time and circumstances of the Reporting Entity becoming aware of the [key contents of the Inside Information]?

ii.	If the Reporting Entity was aware of the [key contents of the Inside Information] prior to the date of this letter, please advise why the Reporting Entity did not Disclose the Inside Information or request a Trading Halt or Suspension at an earlier time?  Please comment specifically on the application of Rule 7.2.1.

(iii)	If the answer to question i) is “no”, please confirm the basis on which the Reporting Entity does not consider the information to be Inside Information?

(iv)	Please confirm that the Reporting Entity is in compliance with the Markets Rules and, in particular, Rule 7.2.1.

question: How must an Authorised Person determine the amount of its Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital when it has private sector credit exposures in multiple jurisdictions, including how the weighted average of the applicable jurisdictional buffer rates is computed and then applied to the Total Risk Exposure Amount?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must set its Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital as a product of (i) its Total Risk Exposure Amount and (ii) a weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates applicable to the jurisdictions where its private sector credit exposures are located. [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] The Total Risk Exposure Amount used in this calculation is the Total Risk Exposure Amount calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7, and the weighted average rate must be calculated in accordance with the specified rules for determining that weighted average. [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] To compute the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates across jurisdictions, the Authorised Person must: (1) for each jurisdiction in which it has private sector credit exposures, take the Total Risk Exposure Amount that relates to the private sector credit exposures in that jurisdiction, divide it by the Total Risk Exposure Amount that relates to the Authorised Person’s private sector credit exposures across all jurisdictions, and multiply the result by the applicable Countercyclical Capital Buffer rate in that jurisdiction; and then (2) sum these jurisdiction-level contributions across all jurisdictions. [#TGT:e71f9d6c-0033-443d-9ce0-aa873bdd8124] The resulting weighted average rate is then multiplied by the Total Risk Exposure Amount to yield the required Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital. [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c]
source_text: An Authorised Person must calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital equal to its Total Risk Exposure Amount, calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7, multiplied by the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to exposures in the jurisdictions where the Authorised Person's private sector credit exposures are located, calculated in accordance with Rules 3.18.5 to 3.18.8.
target_text:
Weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates. The weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates shall be calculated by:
(a)	for each jurisdiction in which the Authorised Person has private sector credit exposures, dividing the Total Risk Exposure Amount that relates to the private sector credit exposures in that jurisdiction by the Total Risk Exposure Amount that relates to the Authorised Person's private sector credit exposures across all jurisdictions and multiplying it by the applicable Countercyclical Capital Buffer rate in that jurisdiction; and
(b)	summing those contributions across all jurisdictions.

question: Where a person is prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus, and an investor who acquired Securities suffers loss from an untrue or misleading statement or a material omission in that Prospectus, what publication-related steps (and timing relative to acquisition) can prevent that person from incurring liability for the loss, including the case where the issue is that an Expert was not competent or did not consent?
gold_answer: A person who is prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus can be liable to pay compensation to an acquirer of the relevant Securities for loss or damage caused by an untrue or misleading statement in the Prospectus, or by omitting a material matter that was required to be included. [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac] However, that person does not incur liability for loss in respect of the Securities if, before the Securities were acquired, either (i) a correction was published in a way intended to reach persons likely to acquire those Securities, or (ii) where the statement is of the type attributed to an Expert, the fact that the Expert was not competent or had not consented to inclusion of the attributed statement was published in that same attention-getting manner. [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b] Alternatively, liability is avoided if the person took all steps that it was reasonable to take to secure that publication and, on reasonable grounds, believed the publication had occurred before the Securities were acquired. [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b] The key linkage is that the compensation exposure tied to untrue/misleading statements or material omissions is addressed by timely, appropriately targeted publication (or reasonable efforts and belief of publication) occurring before acquisition. [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac] [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b]
source_text:
Without prejudice to (2) and (3), a Person does not incur any liability under section 70(1) of the FSMR for any loss in respect of any Securities caused by any statement or omission as is mentioned in that Article if:
(a)	before the Securities were acquired by any Person, a correction or, where the statement was such as is mentioned in (2)(c), the fact that the Expert was not competent or had not consented to the inclusion of the statement attributed to that Expert in the Prospectus had been published in a manner designed to bring to the attention of Persons likely to acquire the Securities in question; or
(b)	he took all such steps as it was reasonable for him to take to secure such publication and believed on reasonable grounds that such a publication had taken place before the Securities were acquired.
target_text: Any person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus is liable to pay compensation to another person who has acquired Securities to which the Prospectus relates and who has suffered loss or damage arising from any untrue or misleading statement in the Prospectus or the omission from it of any material matter required to have been included in the Prospectus by or under these Regulations.

question: If someone is listed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus, and an investor buys the Securities and loses money because the Prospectus had an untrue or misleading statement or left out a required material matter, what can that liable person prove or do to avoid civil liability—especially what must happen before the investor acquires the Securities relying on the Prospectus?
gold_answer: If a person is prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus, they can be required to pay compensation to a person who acquired the Securities covered by that Prospectus and suffered loss or damage because of an untrue or misleading statement or because a required material matter was omitted. [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac] Even in that setting, the person can avoid incurring civil liability if they can demonstrate one of the defenses that focus on truthfulness, reasonable investigation, or prompt correction before acquisition. [#SRC:4ce33793-6bb5-4bc3-a65f-675a4ac19554] In practice, the liable person must be able to show at least one of these: the statement was actually true (and not false, misleading, or deceptive), or the omitted matter that caused the loss was properly left out; they made all enquiries that were reasonable in the circumstances and believed the Prospectus contained no false, misleading, or deceptive statement or omission; or, crucially, before the Securities were acquired by anyone relying on the Prospectus, they took all steps that were reasonable for them to take to get a correction made promptly and to bring that correction to the attention of people likely to acquire the Securities. [#SRC:4ce33793-6bb5-4bc3-a65f-675a4ac19554]
source_text:
A Person does not incur civil liability under section 70(1) of the FSMR if that Person can show that:
(a)	the statement was true and not false, misleading, or deceptive or that the matter the omission of which caused the loss was properly omitted;
(b)	he made all enquiries that were reasonable in the circumstances and believed that there was no false, misleading, or deceptive statement or omission in the Prospectus; or
(c)	before the Securities were acquired by any Person in reliance on the Prospectus, he had taken all such steps as were reasonable for him to have taken to secure that a correction was promptly made and brought to the attention of the Persons likely to acquire the Securities in question.
target_text: Any person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus is liable to pay compensation to another person who has acquired Securities to which the Prospectus relates and who has suffered loss or damage arising from any untrue or misleading statement in the Prospectus or the omission from it of any material matter required to have been included in the Prospectus by or under these Regulations.

question: If an ADGM Green Portfolio has (1) assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy under Rule 3.8.4(a) and (2) assets that track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark under Rule 3.8.4(b), which part needs the third-party attestation and how often must it be done?
gold_answer: Only the portion of Eligible Green Portfolio Assets invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy under Rule 3.8.4(a) is subject to the Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement, while the portion included in or otherwise tracking an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark under Rule 3.8.4(b) is excluded from that requirement. [#TGT:8c92c1b5-2b0d-41a3-b4f4-1b590557042e] [#SRC:9c6ac3b6-ffca-4e6e-a0d2-7252f3e4be86] For the in-scope (taxonomy-aligned) portion, the Authorised Person acting as Investment Manager of an ADGM Green Portfolio must appoint a third party to attest to compliance with the Green Portfolio Investment Requirement. [#TGT:8c92c1b5-2b0d-41a3-b4f4-1b590557042e] The attestation must be maintained on an ongoing basis and performed at least annually for that in-scope portion. [#TGT:8c92c1b5-2b0d-41a3-b4f4-1b590557042e] By contrast, Rule 3.8.6 states that the Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement does not apply to Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark in accordance with Rule 3.8.4(b), so those assets should not be counted when determining what the third party must attest to. [#SRC:9c6ac3b6-ffca-4e6e-a0d2-7252f3e4be86] This means the Investment Manager should apply the attestation only to the taxonomy-aligned slice and exclude the benchmark-tracking slice. [#TGT:8c92c1b5-2b0d-41a3-b4f4-1b590557042e] [#SRC:9c6ac3b6-ffca-4e6e-a0d2-7252f3e4be86]
source_text: Under Rule 3.8.6, the Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement does not apply to Eligible Green Portfolio Assets which are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark in accordance with Rule ‎3.8.4(b).
target_text: The Green Porftolio Attestation Requirement. The Authorised Person acting as Investment Manager of an ADGM Green Portfolio must appoint a third party to attest to its compliance with the Green Portfolio Investment Requirement on an ongoing basis and at least annually. This requirement only applies to that portion of the Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that is invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy in accordance with Rule ‎3.8.4(a). This requirement is referred to as the “Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement”.

question: An Issuer plans to admit its Securities to trading on a MTF and wants to run a single fundraising that includes (i) an offer to no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients and (ii) a parallel offer to Professional Clients. Under the described framework, how can the Issuer structure this as Exempt Offers, and what specific Exempt Offer circumstance is not available when relying on additional circumstances alongside the 200-Person MTF route?
gold_answer: The Issuer can structure the fundraising as simultaneous Exempt Offers by combining the specific 200-Person route tied to admission to trading on a MTF with a separate Exempt Offer directed at Professional Clients. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42] The 200-Person limb is available where an Exempt Offer is directed to no more than 200 Persons who do not qualify as Professional Clients and the Securities are to be admitted to trading on a MTF. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42] In parallel, the Issuer may make an Exempt Offer to (or directed at only) Professional Clients, which is a prescribed Exempt Offer circumstance. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] When the Issuer is seeking admission to trading on an MTF using the 200-Person route, it may also rely on one or more other Exempt Offer circumstances, but it cannot rely on the circumstance corresponding to MKT Rule 4.3.1(2). [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42] This means the combined structure can use the 200-Person MTF-based Exempt Offer plus the Professional Client-only Exempt Offer, while excluding the specific additional circumstance that is carved out. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42]
source_text: MKT Rule 4.3.1(13) provides for the specific circumstance where an Exempt Offer can be directed to no more than 200 Persons who do not qualify as Professional Clients, where the Securities are to be admitted to trading on a MTF.  An Issuer seeking admission to trading of its Securities on an MTF in accordance with MKT Rule 4.3.1(13) may also, pursuant to MKT Rule 4.3.3, utilise an Exempt Offer that relies on one or more of the circumstances within MKT Rule 4.3.1, with the exception of MKT Rule 4.3.1(2).  For example, an Issuer may make a simultaneous Exempt Offer to 200 Persons under MKT rule 4.3.1(13), and an unlimited number of Professional Clients under MKT Rule 4.3.1(1).

question: For a Reporting Entity, how do the section 82 FSMR obligation to appoint an auditor and the requirement that the auditor be appointed in accordance with Part 15 and any Rules made for that Part operate together when making the appointment?
gold_answer: A Reporting Entity must ensure it has an auditor and that the appointment is made through the specific framework referenced for auditor appointments. [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb] The baseline obligation is that the Reporting Entity is required to appoint an auditor under section 82 of the FSMR, so the entity cannot omit making an appointment. [#SRC:0b00ca08-6924-419e-b76d-dd66e5575a33] In addition, the appointment is not merely a general designation; it must be carried out in accordance with Part 15 and any Rules made for the purposes of that Part, meaning the Reporting Entity must follow that Part 15/Rules pathway when appointing the auditor. [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb] Read together, section 82 establishes the duty to appoint, while the Part 15 and related Rules condition specifies the required method or procedural basis for how the auditor is appointed. [#SRC:0b00ca08-6924-419e-b76d-dd66e5575a33] [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb] Accordingly, compliance requires both (i) making an auditor appointment and (ii) ensuring that appointment is made under the Part 15 and Rules framework, rather than outside it. [#SRC:0b00ca08-6924-419e-b76d-dd66e5575a33] [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb]
source_text: A Reporting Entity is required under section 82 of the FSMR to appoint an auditor.
target_text:
Financial reports. Appointment of auditors
A Reporting Entity shall have an auditor Appointed in accordance with ‎Part 15 and any Rules made for the purposes of that Part.

question: If an Authorised Person is allowed (by its Financial Service Permission) to hold Client Money while doing Investment Business, what report has to go to the Regulator every year, and what does the Auditor have to say in it at the date of the audited statement of financial position?
gold_answer: Where an Authorised Person engaged in Investment Business has a Financial Service Permission that allows it to hold Client Money, it must arrange for a Client Money Auditor’s Report to be submitted to the Regulator each year. [#SRC:c42abaa9-4c93-4d5b-b989-aa4ec57cf600] When the Authorised Person procures that report, it must ensure the Auditor includes specific statements measured as at the date the Authorised Person’s audited statement of financial position was prepared. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17] At that financial-position date, the Auditor must state the amount of Client Money the Authorised Person was holding and controlling in line with COBS Chapter 14. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17] The Auditor must also state whether the Authorised Person maintained systems and controls throughout the year to comply with COBS Chapter 14, and whether those controls keep Client Money identifiable and secure at all times. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17] In addition, the Auditor must address whether any COBS Chapter 14 requirements were not met and whether Client Money was pooled in a single client Account or segregated into Client Accounts for individual Clients in accordance with COBS Chapter 14. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17] Finally, the Auditor must confirm receiving necessary information and explanations for the report to the Regulator and, if applicable, note any material reconciliation discrepancies. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17]
source_text: An Authorised Person engaged in Investment Business whose Financial Service Permission entitles them to hold Client Money must also arrange for a Client Money Auditor's Report to be submitted to the Regulator on an annual basis in accordance with GEN 6.6.6.

question: If an Authorised Person wants to change its existing Financial Services Permission so it can do several new Regulated Activities in one go, what fee does it pay, and how do the “highest fee” and “extra activity” fee rules work together with the Rule 3.2.1 fee list?
gold_answer: If an Authorised Person applies to amend an existing Financial Services Permission so it can undertake additional Regulated Activities, it must pay the Regulator the application fees that apply to those additional Regulated Activities as set out in Rule 3.2.1. [#SRC:f02f1e7a-a3ea-47cf-94df-8656a695fbd0] When the same amendment application includes multiple additional Regulated Activities at the same time, the total is not simply a single flat amount; instead, the Authorised Person must pay the highest of the relevant application fees for the Regulated Activities included in that application. [#TGT:4797c128-c19a-4af6-89ba-59fb6b9ac4d2] On top of that highest fee, each additional Regulated Activity included in that same application triggers an extra application fee, and that extra fee is capped: it is the lesser of $10,000 or the application fee specified in these Rules for that Regulated Activity. [#TGT:4797c128-c19a-4af6-89ba-59fb6b9ac4d2] In other words, Rule 3.2.1 provides the underlying fee amounts for the activities being requested, and the multi-activity rule tells you to start with the highest applicable fee and then add a capped incremental fee for each other activity requested at the same time. [#SRC:f02f1e7a-a3ea-47cf-94df-8656a695fbd0] [#TGT:4797c128-c19a-4af6-89ba-59fb6b9ac4d2]
source_text:
Amendment of a Financial Services Permission other than the addition of a Regulated Activity
(a)	Subject to Rule 2.1(c), an Authorised Person applying to amend the scope of an existing Financial Service Permission to enable it to undertake additional Regulated Activities must pay to the Regulator such application fees as set out in Rule 3.2.1.
(b)	An Authorised Person applying to amend the scope of an existing Financial Services Permission to enable it to serve Retail Clients, other than pursuant to Rule 3.20.1, must pay to the Regulator an application fee of $5,000.
(c)	An Authorised Person applying to amend the scope of an existing Financial Services Permission to enable it to conduct Islamic Financial Business must pay to the Regulator an application fee of $5,000.
(d)	An Authorised Person applying to amend the scope of an existing Financial Services Permission through the amendment or removal of a condition, other than in accordance with (b) or (c), must pay to the Regulator an application fee of $5,000.
target_text:
In respect of:
(a)	an Applicant seeking to obtain a Financial Service Permission enabling the Applicant to undertake multiple Regulated Activities; or
(b)	an Authorised Person seeking to amend a Financial Service Permission to enable it to undertake one or more additional Regulated Activities.
the Applicant or Authorised Person, as the case may be, must pay the highest of the relevant application fees associated with the Regulated Activities being applied for at that time.  Each additional Regulated Activity applied for at that time shall incur an additional application fee of the lesser of $10,000 or the application fee specified in these Rules.

question: When an Authorised Person applies to amend the scope of an existing Financial Services Permission to undertake one or more additional Regulated Activities, how must the application fee be calculated, and how does that calculation interact with the requirement to pay the application fees set out in Rule 3.2.1?
gold_answer: For an Authorised Person seeking to amend an existing Financial Services Permission to add one or more additional Regulated Activities, the fee outcome is determined by combining (i) the obligation to pay the applicable application fees for the additional Regulated Activities and (ii) the method for calculating the total when multiple Regulated Activities are applied for at the same time. The Authorised Person must pay the Regulator the application fees for the additional Regulated Activities as set out in Rule 3.2.1. [#SRC:f02f1e7a-a3ea-47cf-94df-8656a695fbd0] Where the amendment request covers multiple additional Regulated Activities at that time, the Authorised Person must pay the highest of the relevant application fees associated with the Regulated Activities being applied for at that time. [#TGT:4797c128-c19a-4af6-89ba-59fb6b9ac4d2] In addition, each extra Regulated Activity included in the same application (beyond the one driving the “highest” fee) triggers an additional fee, calculated as the lesser of $10,000 or the application fee specified in these Rules for that Regulated Activity. [#TGT:4797c128-c19a-4af6-89ba-59fb6b9ac4d2] Practically, this means the Rule 3.2.1 fee schedule supplies the relevant per-activity fees, while the multi-activity rule determines that the payable amount is anchored by the highest applicable fee plus capped incremental fees for each additional activity in the same submission. [#SRC:f02f1e7a-a3ea-47cf-94df-8656a695fbd0] [#TGT:4797c128-c19a-4af6-89ba-59fb6b9ac4d2]

Each additional Regulated Activity applied for at that time shall incur an additional application fee of the lesser of $10,000 or the application fee specified in these Rules.

question: If an Authorised Person is working out its Countercyclical Capital Buffer, what does it have to treat as the “jurisdiction” for each private sector credit exposure, and how is that used in the final buffer calculation?
gold_answer: For the Countercyclical Capital Buffer calculation, the Authorised Person must treat the jurisdiction of a private sector credit exposure as the place where the underlying credit risk ultimately originates, based on the best identification it can make. [#TGT:ffc672ed-a781-4a71-bb0d-7fc38a2e0c7c] That jurisdiction identification matters because the buffer is calculated by taking the Authorised Person’s Total Risk Exposure Amount and multiplying it by a weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to exposures in the jurisdictions where those private sector credit exposures are located. [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] In other words, the “location” step determines which jurisdictional buffer rates are considered “applicable” for the weighted average, and the weighted average then directly drives the size of the buffer when applied to the Total Risk Exposure Amount. [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] The Authorised Person must therefore link each exposure to a jurisdiction by tracing the ultimate origin of the credit risk, and then use those jurisdictions’ rates in the weighted-average component of the buffer formula. [#TGT:ffc672ed-a781-4a71-bb0d-7fc38a2e0c7c]
source_text: An Authorised Person must calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital equal to its Total Risk Exposure Amount, calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7, multiplied by the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to exposures in the jurisdictions where the Authorised Person's private sector credit exposures are located, calculated in accordance with Rules 3.18.5 to 3.18.8.
target_text: Geographical location. For the purposes of the calculation of the weighted average of the applicable Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates an Authorised Person must identify, to the best of its ability, the geographical location of its private sector credit exposures as the jurisdiction where the underlying credit risk ultimately originates.

question: If a Recognised Investment Exchange wants to admit Units in a closed-ended Investment Fund to trading, what must its Business Rules achieve, and what closed-ended fund checks should it use to decide whether trading will be fair, orderly and efficient?
gold_answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange can admit Financial Instruments to trading only if its Business Rules ensure that instruments admitted to trading are capable of being traded in a fair, orderly and efficient manner. [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215] For Units in a closed-ended Investment Fund, the way it should judge whether that “fair, orderly and efficient” standard is met is by taking into account two specific fund features: how widely the Units are distributed to the public, and whether the value of the Units is made sufficiently transparent to investors. [#SRC:72e47a23-5aa5-4df1-a4d6-2aaf037e9131] The value-transparency element can be satisfied, for this assessment, either through publication of information about the Fund’s investment strategy or through periodic publication of a net asset value. [#SRC:72e47a23-5aa5-4df1-a4d6-2aaf037e9131] Accordingly, the Business Rules should not just state the general trading-quality requirement; they should be applied through an admission review that explicitly checks those closed-ended fund factors so the Recognised Investment Exchange can conclude the Units will trade fairly, orderly and efficiently on its market. [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215]
source_text:
Units in collective investment funds
When assessing whether Units are capable of being traded in a fair, orderly and efficient manner for the purposes of Rule 3.9.1, a Recognised Investment Exchange shall take the following aspects into account:
(a)	For an open-ended Collective Investment Fund:
(i)	the distribution of those Units to the public;
(ii)	whether there are appropriate market-making arrangements, or whether the Fund Manager provides appropriate alternative arrangements for investors to redeem the Units; and
(iii)	whether the value of the units is made sufficiently transparent to investors by means of the periodic publication of the net asset value.
(b)	For a closed-ended Investment Fund:
(i)	the distribution of those Units to the public; and
(ii)	whether the value of the Units is made sufficiently transparent to investors, either by publication of information on the Fund's investment strategy or by the periodic publication of a net asset value.
target_text:
Admission to trading
In order to admit Financial Instruments to trading, a Recognised Investment Exchange must satisfy the following requirements, save and except for Recognised Investment Exchanges which only admit to trading Derivatives, in which case only (a), (b), (c) and (i) apply:
(a)	A Recognised Investment Exchange’s Business Rules must be clear and transparent in relation to the admission of Financial Instruments to trading on any market operated by it.
(b)	The Business Rules must ensure that all Financial Instruments admitted to trading on any market operated by the Recognised Investment Exchange are capable of being traded in a fair, orderly and efficient manner.
(c)	The Business Rules must ensure that:
(i)	all Financial Instruments other than Derivatives admitted to trading on a market operated by the Recognised Investment Exchange are freely negotiable; and
(ii)	all contracts for Derivatives admitted to trading on a regulated market operated by the Recognised Investment Exchange are designed so as to allow for their orderly pricing as well as for the existence of effective settlement conditions.
(d)	For the purposes of meeting the requirements in Rule 3.9.1(c)(ii), a Recognised Investment Exchange must include in its Business Rules, or its Business Rule procedures, contract design specifications relating to Derivative contracts traded on its market which, at a minimum, include:
(i)	minimum price fluctuations (price ticks);
(ii)	maximum price fluctuations (daily price limits), if any;
(iii)	last trading day;
(iv)	settlement or delivery procedures as applicable;
(v)	trading months;
(vi)	position limits, if any;
(vii)	reportable levels; and
(viii)	trading hours.
(e)	The Recognised Investment Exchange must maintain effective arrangements to verify that Issuers of Financial Instruments admitted to trading on a market operated by it comply with its disclosure obligations.
(f)	The Recognised Investment Exchange must maintain arrangements to assist users of a market operated by it to obtain access to information made public under its disclosure obligations.
(g)	The Recognised Investment Exchange must maintain arrangements regularly to review whether the Financial Instruments admitted to trading on a market operated by it comply with the admission requirements for those Financial Instruments.
(h)	The Business Rules must provide that where a Recognised Investment Exchange, without obtaining the consent of the Issuer, admits to trading on a market operated by it a Financial Instrument which has been admitted to trading on another market, the Recognised Investment Exchange:
(i)	must inform the Issuer of that Financial Instrument as soon as is reasonably practicable; and
(ii)	may not require the Issuer of that Financial Instrument to demonstrate compliance with its disclosure obligations.
(i)	The Business Rules must provide that where a Recognised Investment Exchange, without obtaining the consent of the Issuer, admits to trading on an MTF operated by it a Financial Instrument which has been admitted to trading on a market, it may not require the Issuer of that Financial Instrument to demonstrate compliance with its disclosure obligations.
(j)	A Recognised Investment Exchange must comply with the requirements of Rule 3.11 where it admits to trading on a market operated by it a Financial Instrument, the value of which is determined by reference to an underlying benchmark or index provided by a Price Reporting Agency.

question: Where a Listed Entity has issued, or agreed to issue, Securities without prior approval, under what conditions is that issue treated as approved for Rule 9.7.1 purposes, and how does that treatment affect whether those Securities are excluded from “Relevant Issues” when applying the 20% formula restriction on new Issues of Equity Securities?
gold_answer: An unapproved issue (or agreement to issue) Securities can be treated as if it had approval for Rule 9.7.1, but only if three conditions are met: it stayed within the Rule 9.7.1 limit, the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities later approve it, and the Securities are then issued within three months after that approval date. [#SRC:3f609871-988e-4e0c-921f-6e1066c630f6] Once that subsequent approval treatment applies, the issue is treated as having approval “for the purposes of Rule 9.7.1,” which matters when calculating the restriction on new issues because “Relevant Issues” excludes Equity Securities issued or agreed to be issued in the prior 12 months if they were made with approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 (or Rule 9.7.5). [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] In practical terms, if the Securities are Equity Securities and the subsequent-approval conditions are satisfied, the Listed Entity can treat them as approved under Rule 9.7.1 for the exclusion test in the “Relevant Issues” definition, rather than counting them toward the prior-12-month total that reduces the maximum number available under the 20% * Base Amount formula. [#SRC:3f609871-988e-4e0c-921f-6e1066c630f6] [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]
source_text:
Subsequent approval of an issue of Securities. An issue of, or agreement to issue, Securities made without approval under Rule 9.7.1 is treated as having been made with approval for the purposes of Rule 9.7.1 if:
(1)	the issue or agreement did not exceed the limit in Rule 9.7.1;
(2)	the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities subsequently approve it; and
(3)	the Securities are issued within three months of the date of the approval.
target_text:
Restrictions on new Issues of Equity Securities . A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the number calculated according to the following formula, without the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities:
Maximum number of Equity Securities = (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues),
where:
Base Amount = the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities on issue as of the date 12 months before the date of issue or agreement (the “12 months Base Amount”), plus the number of:
(1)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exceptions (8), (15) or (16);
(2)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exception (15), where the agreement was:
(i)	entered into before the commencement of the 12 month period; or
(ii)	approved, or taken under the Rules to have been approved, under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; and
(3)	any other fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5;
Guidance
The Base Amount may include fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an agreement to issue Securities within Rule 9.7.4 exception (14) where the issue is subsequently approved under Rule 9.7.1.
(4)	partly paid Ordinary Securities that became fully paid in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement,
but subtracting the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities cancelled in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement.
Relevant Issues = the number of Equity Securities issued, or agreed to be issued, in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement to issue other than:
(a)	with the approval of the holders of its Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; or
(b)	under an exception in Rule 9.7.4.

question: When assessing potential contravention of section 92(2) (Insider Dealing), how should a firm distinguish between (i) a person merely executing their own pre-formed intention to deal and (ii) dealing on the basis of “Inside Information” for Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, or Accepted Spot Commodities (including Related Instruments that are not Commodity Derivatives)?
gold_answer: A person’s execution of their own pre-formed intention to deal, by itself, is treated as not breaching section 92(2) (Insider Dealing); the compliance focus therefore shifts to whether the dealing is instead connected to “Inside Information” as defined for the relevant instruments. [#SRC:78dea780-e39f-407d-855f-5cb46c1b30d7] For Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, Accepted Spot Commodities, and Related Instruments that are not Commodity Derivatives, “Inside Information” is limited to information that is precise, not generally available, and that relates (directly or indirectly) to one or more Reporting Entities or Issuers or to the instruments themselves, and that would likely move the price significantly if it became generally available. [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977] In practical terms, the firm should (1) confirm the person formed an intention to deal before dealing and recognize that carrying out that intention alone is not the contravention trigger, [#SRC:78dea780-e39f-407d-855f-5cb46c1b30d7] and (2) separately test whether any information influencing the trade meets all elements of the “Inside Information” definition (precise, non-public, relevant to Reporting Entities/Issuers or the instruments, and price-significant). [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977] This linkage matters because the “own intention” concept addresses the act of dealing, while the “Inside Information” definition supplies the characteristics of information that could make dealing problematic under an insider dealing analysis. [#SRC:78dea780-e39f-407d-855f-5cb46c1b30d7] [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977]
source_text: Carrying out of own trading intention. A person will form an intention to deal in a Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity before doing so. His carrying out of his own intention will not of itself contravene section 92(2) (Insider Dealing).
target_text:
In relation to Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, Accepted Spot Commodities or Related Instruments which are not Commodity Derivatives, Inside Information is information of a Precise nature which—
(a)	is not generally available;
(b)	relates, directly or indirectly, to one or more Reporting Entities or Issuers of the Financial Instruments or to one or more of the Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities; and
(c)	would, if generally available, be likely to have a significant effect on the price of the Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, Accepted Spot Commodities or Related Instruments.

question: In a case involving an ADGM Branch where the Non-ADGM Institution is subject to a Foreign Resolution Action, what combination of (i) the conditions that must be satisfied before a Resolution Action may be taken in respect of the ADGM Branch and (ii) the Regulator’s discretion to refuse recognition based on unequal treatment of ADGM creditors, determines whether the Regulator can both proceed with ADGM Branch Resolution Action and decline recognition of the foreign action?
gold_answer: Where the Non-ADGM Institution is subject to a Foreign Resolution Action, a Resolution Action may still be taken in respect of an ADGM Branch only if the Regulator is satisfied that the branch is failing or likely to fail, that (given timing and other relevant circumstances) it is not reasonably likely that other action will prevent the failure or likely failure, and that use of a Resolution Tool is in the public interest. [#SRC:f586c998-e0a5-470f-a8d5-ae1669514726] In that same scenario, the Regulator must also be satisfied that, although the Non-ADGM Institution is subject to Foreign Resolution Action, one of the specified circumstances applies in respect of the Non-ADGM Institution. [#SRC:f586c998-e0a5-470f-a8d5-ae1669514726] Separately, even if the Regulator is considering recognition of the Foreign Resolution Action, it may refuse to recognise it (in whole or in part) if it is satisfied that, under the foreign action, creditors located or payable in the ADGM would not receive the same treatment and similar legal rights as creditors (including depositors) located or payable in the relevant non-ADGM jurisdiction, where the difference arises because the creditors are located in the ADGM. [#TGT:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba] Therefore, the Regulator can proceed with ADGM Branch Resolution Action only if the ADGM-Branch conditions are met, while it can simultaneously decline recognition if the foreign action would disadvantage ADGM creditors compared with non-ADGM creditors. [#SRC:f586c998-e0a5-470f-a8d5-ae1669514726] [#TGT:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba]
source_text:
A Resolution Action may be taken in respect of an ADGM Branch only if the Regulator is satisfied that the following conditions are met—
(a)	the ADGM Branch is failing or is likely to fail;
(b)	having regard to timing and other relevant circumstances, it is not reasonably likely that any action will be taken by or in respect of the ADGM Branch or Non-ADGM Institution that will prevent the failure or likely failure of the ADGM Branch or Non-ADGM Institution;
(c)	the application of a Resolution Tool is in the public interest; and
(d)	the Non-ADGM Institution is—
(i)	not subject to, and not likely in a reasonable timeframe to be subject to, any Foreign Resolution Action or Non-ADGM Insolvency Proceedings; or
(ii)	subject to Foreign Resolution Action, and one of the circumstances referred to in section 78(2) applies in respect of the Non-ADGM Institution.

question: If an Authorised Person has private sector credit exposures in more than one jurisdiction, what steps does it follow to work out the weighted average Countercyclical Capital Buffer rate and then calculate the Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital?
gold_answer: Where an Authorised Person has private sector credit exposures in multiple jurisdictions, it must calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital by multiplying its Total Risk Exposure Amount by a weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply in the jurisdictions where those exposures are located. [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] The Total Risk Exposure Amount used for this purpose is the Total Risk Exposure Amount calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7, and the weighted average rate must be determined using the prescribed method for jurisdictional weighting. [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] The weighted average rate is built up jurisdiction by jurisdiction. For each jurisdiction where the Authorised Person has private sector credit exposures, it must calculate that jurisdiction’s contribution by taking the Total Risk Exposure Amount related to private sector credit exposures in that jurisdiction, dividing it by the Total Risk Exposure Amount related to the Authorised Person’s private sector credit exposures across all jurisdictions, and multiplying by the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rate applicable in that jurisdiction. [#TGT:e71f9d6c-0033-443d-9ce0-aa873bdd8124] It must then add together all of those jurisdiction contributions to get the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates. [#TGT:e71f9d6c-0033-443d-9ce0-aa873bdd8124] Finally, it applies that weighted average rate to the Total Risk Exposure Amount to arrive at the Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital. [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c]
source_text: An Authorised Person must calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital equal to its Total Risk Exposure Amount, calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7, multiplied by the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to exposures in the jurisdictions where the Authorised Person's private sector credit exposures are located, calculated in accordance with Rules 3.18.5 to 3.18.8.
target_text:
Weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates. The weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates shall be calculated by:
(a)	for each jurisdiction in which the Authorised Person has private sector credit exposures, dividing the Total Risk Exposure Amount that relates to the private sector credit exposures in that jurisdiction by the Total Risk Exposure Amount that relates to the Authorised Person's private sector credit exposures across all jurisdictions and multiplying it by the applicable Countercyclical Capital Buffer rate in that jurisdiction; and
(b)	summing those contributions across all jurisdictions.

question: If a Recognised Body is not meeting the Recognition Requirements, when would the Regulator tell it to take steps (like letting the Regulator inspect its premises or pausing activities) instead of moving to revoke the Recognition Order, and what time-based business inactivity situations can also lead to revocation?
gold_answer: The Regulator can direct a Recognised Body to take specified steps to secure compliance with the Recognition Requirements, but it will usually consider revoking the Recognition Order in defined situations where directions are not enough or not suitable. [#TGT:83e95cf0-0fcf-4cb3-ab07-0404f8736500] Directions can require practical measures such as giving the Regulator access to the Recognised Body’s premises to inspect the premises or documents there, and suspending the carrying on of any activity for a period set out in the direction. [#TGT:83e95cf0-0fcf-4cb3-ab07-0404f8736500] However, revocation is usually considered if the Recognised Body is failing or has failed to satisfy one or more Recognition Requirements and that failure has or will have serious consequences. [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a] Revocation is also usually considered if it would not be possible for the Recognised Body to comply with a direction, or if (for some other reason) it would not be appropriate for the Regulator to give a direction. [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a] In addition, the Regulator will usually consider revocation where the Recognised Body has not carried on the business of a Recognised Body during the 12 months beginning when the Recognition Order took effect, or where it has not carried on that business at any time during the six months ending on the day the Recognition Order is revoked. [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a]
target_text: The Regulator has the power to give directions to a Recognised Body to take specified steps in order to secure its compliance with the Recognition Requirements. Those steps may include granting the Regulator access to the Recognised Body's premises for the purposes of inspecting those premises or any documents on the premises and the suspension of the carrying on of any activity by the Recognised Body for the period specified in the direction.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity already made a full Rule 11.8.2 Production Target disclosure, when can it make a later update without repeating all the details (like the assumptions and the split between Ore Reserves/Mineral Resources/Exploration Target), and what must it still say if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources or partly based on an Exploration Target?
gold_answer: A later disclosure about a Production Target does not have to repeat all the detailed Rule 11.8.2 information (for example, the material economic assumptions and other material assumptions, whether forecast commodity prices were used on reasonable grounds, and the proportions sourced from Ore Reserves, Mineral Resources, Inferred Mineral Resources, and any Exploration Target) if it properly relies on an earlier Rule 11.8.2 disclosure that already included those items and was compliant. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] To do that, the later disclosure must refer back to the earlier compliant disclosure and must also confirm that the material assumptions from the initial disclosure still apply and have not materially changed. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] Even when the later disclosure is streamlined, it still needs to include specific prominent warnings in certain cases: if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, the later disclosure must include an at least equally prominent and proximate statement matching the required Inferred Mineral Resources warning for that scenario. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] If the Production Target is based in part on an Exploration Target, the later disclosure must include an at least equally prominent and proximate statement matching the required Exploration Target warning. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the Production Target:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed; or
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	if forecast commodity prices have been used in the determination of the Production Target, a statement that such forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds.
(3)	the proportions of the Production Target based on:
(a)	Probable Ore Reserves and Proved Ore Reserves;
(b)	Indicated Mineral Resources and Measured Mineral Resources;
(c)	Inferred Mineral Resources; and
(d)	an Exploration Target.
(4)	a statement that the respective proportions of Inferred Mineral Resources and the Exploration Target (if applicable) are not the determining factors in the viability of the Production Target and do not feature as a significant proportion in the early mine plan;
(5)	if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources:
(a)	an explanation as to why the Mining Reporting Entity believes it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources;
(b)	the level of confidence in relation to which the Inferred Mineral Resources are estimated and the basis for that level of confidence;
(c)	a Technical Study of a sufficient level of confidence to support the Production Target, prepared by, or under the supervision of, a named independent Competent Person(s); and
(d)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. Though further evaluation and/or exploration work is required to establish sufficient confidence that the production target will be met, there is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.  The mining reporting entity’s production target is based on its current expectation of future results or events, and should not be solely relied upon by investors when making investment decisions.”
Guidance
Any statement about a Production Target will be deemed to be misleading unless the person making the statement has reasonable grounds for making the statement.  The Regulator considers that it is only under exceptional circumstances that a Mining Reporting Entity might form a view that it has reasonable grounds for a Production Target to be wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources.
(6)	if the Production Target is in part based on Inferred Mineral Resources, an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. There is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.”
(7)	if the Production Target is in part based on an Exploration Target:
(a)	a statement of the factors that lead the Mining Reporting Entity to believe that it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target based, in part, on an Exploration Target; and
(b)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The potential quantity and grade of an Exploration Target is only conceptual in nature. There has been insufficient exploration to determine a Mineral Resource and there is no certainty that further exploration work will result in the determination of Mineral Resources or that the Production Target itself will be realised.”

question: When a Payment Order for an individual Payment Transaction is transmitted using a Payment Instrument issued under a Framework Contract, which post-initiation information must the Payment Service Provider still provide immediately after initiation, and what category of information may it omit because another Payment Service Provider provides it under Section 19.2?
gold_answer: For an individual Payment Transaction sent via a Payment Instrument issued under a Framework Contract, the Payment Service Provider must still provide (or make available) the post-initiation, transaction-specific information immediately after the initiation of the Payment Order to the Payer and, where applicable, to the Payee. [#SRC:a48a07c2-0731-4505-939e-07110e2af622] This includes confirmation that initiation with the Payer’s Payment Service Provider was successful, a reference that lets the Payer and Payee identify the Payment Transaction (including identifying the Payer and Payee and, where appropriate, information transferred with the Payment Order), the transaction amount in the currency used in the Payment Order, any charges payable (and where applicable a breakdown in the Payment Order currency), any exchange-rate details and the post-conversion amount where an exchange rate is used, the date the Payment Service Provider received the Payment Order, and the Credit Value Date. [#SRC:a48a07c2-0731-4505-939e-07110e2af622] However, in this Framework Contract/Payment Instrument scenario, the Payment Service Provider for that single Payment Transaction does not need to provide the “general information” that would otherwise be required under Rule 19.5.1, to the extent that such general information has been provided or will be provided under Section 19.2 by another Payment Service Provider in respect of the Framework Contract. [#TGT:c337e2ea-0d58-45b9-970f-810639f88bf2]
target_text: Where a Payment Order for an individual Payment Transaction is transmitted by way of a Payment Instrument issued under a Framework Contract, the Payment Service Provider in respect of that single Payment Transaction need not provide or make available under Rule 19.5.1 the general information which has been provided or will be provided under Section 19.2 by another Payment Service Provider in respect of a Framework Contract.
